contents.title: description
contents.content_html:
Critical Sowing for Earthly survival was a workshop spearheaded by myself and Selma Younis. Selma's thesis is centered around Indigenous urban gardening in Toronto and epistemologies that de-center the human in the 'anthropocene'. For this workshop, we came together to work on a project with a shared goal of reexamining existing structures and knowledge exchange among students from different art and design disciplines.

Selma and I were keen on having conversations about the earth whilst engaging with the very living organisms that rely on it and with it. Hence, this simple knowledge exchange setting shifted into one where the community would be planting seeds and making seed bombs whilst discussing the topics at hand.

Special thanks to Craig Rodmore for guiding Selma and I to each other.
contents.content:
Critical Sowing for Earthly survival was a workshop spearheaded by myself and [Selma Younis](https://www.linkedin.com/in/selma-younis-49699526a/?originalSubdomain=ca). Selma's thesis is centered around Indigenous urban gardening in Toronto and epistemologies that de-center the human in the 'anthropocene'. For this workshop, we came together to work on a project with a shared goal of reexamining existing structures and knowledge exchange among students from different art and design disciplines. 

Selma and I were keen on having conversations about the earth whilst engaging with the very living organisms that rely on it and with it. Hence, this simple knowledge exchange setting shifted into one where the community would be planting seeds and making seed bombs whilst discussing the topics at hand.

Special thanks to Craig Rodmore for guiding Selma and I to each other.

Main Resources

%Ont

13
Reflection 14

Final Video

Mixed media animation was brought to my attention funnily enough
on TikTok. | had come across a creator who was showcasing their
mixed media animation Process. The whole thing looked so exten-
sive and experimental | was drawn to it to sa%/ the least. Not the
mention the beautifully satﬂymg final product which more often
than not looks phenomenal. Mixed Media animation always seemed
like such a forgiving hobby. Ever since then, I've wanted to deleve
into the world of mixed media animation but never got the time or
chance until this project. - :

contents.content_html:
Mixed Media Animation

U

3 YouTube

Lou uses the medium
of paper to push the
boundaries of what can
be achieved with the
rinted medium alone.
sing techniques like
scratching, cutting and
asting to their advan-
tage in creating new and
interesting composi-
tions. Often times, the
use clips of artists an
their music videos to
remix in a way that gives
them a new lite. The first
one | came across was
this one for Lexie Liu.

This is lou 4

The creator | first came
across who explored
mixed media in a way |
hadn’t seen before

MIXED MEDIA ANIMATION

lexie liu FORTUNA mixed media animation

o:

In behind the scenes videos on
Lou’s TikTok account, they can
be seen editing specific parts of
the music video on Photoshop,
adding effects that contrast
with the original overall feel of
the original video. For example,
adding threshold for more tex-
ture or changing the colour lev-
els. After printing these frames,
Lou cuts away parts of the
original music video frames and
attaches the edited ones post
production, as well as drawing
over and painting on top of the
frames, emphasizing the ‘remix’
esque nature of using someone
elses work and giving it a new
life and meaning through the
construction of medium.

/O\ntheir website, Lou

Mixed Media Animation 2

| l
- Ay T

details process frame |
by frame showcasing . ;

the stages and how one
video comes together
using stop motion. They
regularly use analouge
mediums like coloured
pencils and crayons in
their manipulation of
paper to add texture and
personality.

Although Lou isn’t very detailed about the process of how the
compile frames and how they scan and compile images, it’s clear
to see that their work is very relenthless and doesn’t require at-
tention to detail. It's experimental in a beautiful way, where they

are able to embrace new ideas or even mistakes as new ways to
e)épt_a_nment.- They utilize the medium of paper to it’s fullest, using
additive (painting, colouring, drawing, pasting) and subtractive
scratching, tearing, cqttlng% techniques to emphasize the topics
being handled in the video they are animating, as opposed to doing
it for the sake of aesthetic value.

All images on this page belong to lou +

artshoker

contents.title: page4.png
contents.content_html:
Mixed Media Animation

This is Dima 4+

Dima is a friend and an
amazing designer. He
specializes in collage. |
was initially inspired by
him to do this project
because of his GD3
assngnment where he
created a series of stop
motion video collages

I spoke to Dima about his process. He descibed
it as time consuming and intensive. Dima’s tech-
niques are a lot more additive than Lou’s, as
he utilizes collage, adding other-worldly or two
dimentional objects and scenarios to empha-
size, showcase and portray feeling and
severity. In this project, Dima was :
speaking to The on\%lomg

ussian-Ukrainian War
that has been devestat-
ing his home country.

Dima’s process relies
on preciese accuracy
in compasion to Lou’s
which was very forgiv-
ing. His work heavily
relies on the placement
of certian elements on
the page. If they by any
chance aren’t placed
exactly where they
need to be, it

would make

the animation

too abrupt and

choppy.

At first | assumed that Dima has
taken photographs of his work,
but he later clanfied that they
are scans. This adds another
layer of complexity to the work,
as he doesn't exactly get to see
what he is compiling until it is
done scanning.

Mixed Media Animation

This is Dima 4+

Dima is a friend and an
amazing designer. He
specializes in collage. |
was initially inspired by
him to do this project
because of his GD3
assngnment where he
created a series of stop
motion video collages

I spoke to Dima about his process. He descibed
it as time consuming and intensive. Dima’s tech-
niques are a lot more additive than Lou’s, as
he utilizes collage, adding other-worldly or two
dimentional objects and scenarios to empha-
size, showcase and portray feeling and
severity. In this project, Dima was :
speaking to The on\%lomg

ussian-Ukrainian War
that has been devestat-
ing his home country.

Dima’s process relies
on preciese accuracy
in compasion to Lou’s
which was very forgiv-
ing. His work heavily
relies on the placement
of certian elements on
the page. If they by any
chance aren’t placed
exactly where they
need to be, it

would make

the animation

too abrupt and

choppy.

At first | assumed that Dima has
taken photographs of his work,
but he later clanfied that they
are scans. This adds another
layer of complexity to the work,
as he doesn't exactly get to see
what he is compiling until it is
done scanning.

contents.title: page6.png
contents.content_html:
Mixed Media Animation

The main source for my
knowledge was Youtube.
Since mixed media ani-
mation is a lesser known
and iterated form of ani-
mation, there are a select
few videos on youtube
that break down the
whole process the same
way. Because there is no
standard way to do it.

eSOourC

The lack of standardization for this medium allows us to be more
experimental and exploratory, engaging with all kinds of software
and tools. The first step where this took place was creating the
frames. Aimost all Youtube videos showcased using after effects to
export the video into frames. However, | knew from prior exposure
that Photoshop had a feature where you could export a video as
frames, but then again, who is to sto%you from *ust screen shot-
ting the video you want right? Right. However, | found that this is
|ncred|bI¥ tedious and time consuming, so you’re better off using
EZgif or Photoshop.

v Slice Tool Part- 1|
Tutorial | Artose

j mixed media animation // the process + a littie chat + final animation
grid! | PHOTOSHOP TUTORIA

How to Use the Slice Tool in
B Photoshop CC
L]

1 DUMBDAYS! “How to Make Mixed Media Animations + (FREE Pack).” YouTube, June 11, 2023. https://www.youtube.com/
watch?v=-yso7jTmuiw&t=220s&ab_channel=DUMBDAYS%21

2 https://www.youtube.com/shorts/AIA3M3ZKppQ

Mixed Media Animation 8

The second stage was laying
out the frames into colums

and rows. This isn’t standard-
ized either. In Youtube videos, |
watched People use everything
from Photoshop! to e:ézﬁple pag-
es.? Naturally, | picked Indesign,
as it allowed me to upload all of
my frames into rows and col-
umns as i drageed them directly
in the document.

Okay, were gonna
skip a few steps
here. Once the
frames are layed
out, the next step
Is to print them out
and start experi-
menting. But there
was not much
need for resources

in that part of the project. Instead, the need for gl_]id-
ance came after the frames were done being oblit-
erated, decorated and scanned. How was | going to
turn those into a film?

At this sta%e | facilitated the help of Aaryan
Pashine who had (for gégrewc_)us rojec
worked with mixed media animation and
had come up with a ‘hack’ for this. He
directed me to try the slice tool in Photo-
shop. This allowed me to ‘slice’ the parts of
the scanned document that | needed and
export the images within the document. |
realized that once you save images for web,
Photoshop lets you select the exact slices
you want and export specifically those.

eSOourC

The lack of standardization for this medium allows us to be more

Mixed Media Animation 8

The second stage was laying
out the frames into colums

and rows. This isn’t standard-
ized either. In Youtube videos, |
watched People use everything
from Photoshop! to e:ézﬁple pag-
es.? Naturally, | picked Indesign,
as it allowed me to upload all of
my frames into rows and col-
umns as i drageed them directly
in the document.

Okay, were gonna
skip a few steps
here. Once the
frames are layed
out, the next step
Is to print them out
and start experi-
menting. But there
was not much
need for resources

in that part of the project. Instead, the need for gl_]id-
ance came after the frames were done being oblit-
erated, decorated and scanned. How was | going to
turn those into a film?

At this sta%e | facilitated the help of Aaryan
Pashine who had (for gégrewc_)us rojec
worked with mixed media animation and
had come up with a ‘hack’ for this. He
directed me to try the slice tool in Photo-
shop. This allowed me to ‘slice’ the parts of
the scanned document that | needed and
export the images within the document. |
realized that once you save images for web,
Photoshop lets you select the exact slices
you want and export specifically those.

contents.title: description
contents.content_html: A post-documentation publication on my experience learning mixed media animation. The final video is available to view here
contents.content: A post-documentation publication on my experience learning mixed media animation. The final video is available to view [here] (https://runamoto.github.io/parchmentecho/)

contents.title: truck-art_page_0.jpg
contents.content_html:
INTRODUCTION
TAXONOMIES
REGIONAL STYLES

PUNJABISTYLE

SWATI | RAWALPINDI STYLE

BALUCHISTYLE

PESHAWARI STYLE

STYLE SHOWCASE
DECORATIVE MOTIFS

RELIGIOUS SYMBOLS

TALISMANIC SYMBOLISM

DREAM LIVES

POLITICS & POP CULTURE

CALLIGRAPHY

MOTIF SHOWCASE

A CANVAS ON WHEELS

INTRODUCTION

The practice of vehicle decoration is prevalent throughout Southeast
Asia. Countries like India, Bangladesh, Thailand and the Philippines
have been ornamenting their vehicles of transport for centuries and in
their own unique and dazzling ways. Pakistan however, stands out in
the crowd because of their sheer dedication to the craft and it's nation-
al prolific nature. Pakistan's fascination with the pursuit of beautifying
trucks has reached the point where truck art is now an artifact that
many people attribute to the country, many locals have been passing
through as generations of truck artists, and there are countless truck
yards (Ames), workshops (“A Short View of Pakistani truck Workshop”
00:00-04:02) and specialized schools to account for it (“The Beau-
tiful Painted Trucks of Pakistan” 02:02-02:10). The history of how
exactly the craze started is muddy, there is no singular answer. Among
all the contrary stories it becomes an almost mythical tale. Some say it
started in Afghanistan and made it's way to Pakistan during the Afghan
war (Elias 188), some say it started during the separation of Hindustan,
when the British brought Bedford trucks to Pakistan (Sheikh). Some
even date it back to the Indus Valley Civilization (2600 -1700 BC)
when people beautified their boats and transportation animals as we
know through historical remnants (Rathnayake). But this journal isn't
about the history of truck art in Pakistan. In the next few pages we'll
hold a magnifying glass to the details that make these trucks what
they are, how they differ slightly or significantly from region to region
within Pakistan and what exactly constitutes the epitome of maximal-
ism that are the Pakistani trucks, what stories are told though the metal
work, wood work and painting.

A CANVAS ON WHEELS

contents.title: description
contents.content_html:
Canvas on Wheels or Horn Ok Please is a one off publication centered around the art and culture of Pakistani truck art. The publication explores a plethora of images found on the web (mainly flickr) of identifiable truck art motifs and styles in Pakistan and taxonomizes them into regional style and symbolic motif.

The publication highlights how these (predominantly male) drivers view their vehicles as outward representations of themselves— highly ornamental cyborgs if you will. Religious imagery and political figures merely represent a singular plane of the massive 4 sided vehicle many consider to be their kin.
contents.content:
Canvas on Wheels or Horn Ok Please is a one off publication centered around the art and culture of Pakistani truck art. The publication explores a plethora of images found on the web (mainly flickr) of identifiable truck art motifs and styles in Pakistan and taxonomizes them into regional style and symbolic motif. 

The publication highlights how these (predominantly male) drivers view their vehicles as outward representations of themselves— highly ornamental cyborgs if you will. Religious imagery and political figures merely represent a singular plane of the massive 4 sided vehicle many consider to be their kin.

contents.title: description
contents.content_html:
A love letter to Village by the Grange is a broadsheet publication part of a research project conducted over the course of 3 months. It centers around the iconic Village by the Grange building nestled opposite of the Ontario College of Art and design. A go-to for any student, faculty or local who lives in the area. "The Grange" as it is most often referred to has a long, mysterious history that I began to unravel via the internet and the Toronto archives. In this publication, I write about my findings and argue that the grange is in it's truest sense, a "third place"

This publication was a result of my first Independent Study at OCAD under the wing of Ali Qadeer.
contents.content:
A love letter to Village by the Grange is a broadsheet publication part of a research project conducted over the course of 3 months. It centers around the iconic Village by the Grange building nestled opposite of the Ontario College of Art and design. A go-to for any student, faculty or local who lives in the area. "The Grange" as it is most often referred to has a long, mysterious history that I began to unravel via the internet and the Toronto archives. In this publication, I write about my findings and argue that the grange is in it's truest sense, a "third place" 

This publication was a result of my first Independent Study at OCAD under the wing of Ali Qadeer.

contents.content_html:
The Mccaul loop
1980

The McCaul Loop built under one of the Village By The
Grange complexes is currently home to the OCADU
print shop

Toronto City Archives

New Thai Combo Plate

“Grilled chicken (with hot sauce) on a bed of pad
thai-style noodels, with vegetables, from from the
New Thai food stall at The Village by the Grange
Food Court.— Andrew Currie on Flickr”

@® Thai Food

Andrew Currie (photographer & Reviewer)

-

Waffles with Melted Peanut Butter & Fruit

“From the vegetarian joint in my local Food
Court!— Andrew Currie on Flickr”

@ Vegetarian Breakfast

Andrew Currie (| photographer & Reviewer)

McDonald’s

Another contender for one of the longest lasting
places in TVBG. A timeless capitalist masterpiece
and possibly one of the only franchises in the
food court.

@® American Fast Food

V3. on Yelp (photographer)

Outside Patio for Ginsberg & Wong ® Jewish & Chinese
Ginsberg and Wong is still the reason people
know and remember TVBG today. It closed
down during the 1990 economic recession.
“Fairly certain this was the first restaurant I ever
went to when my family immigrated to Canada. T
wanted chicken wings, I instead got strange Chi-
nese take on chicken wings — VAC2023, Reddit”

Village By The Grange food court

Pictured is the most often populated area of the Janice Pearson on Flickr (photographer)

Grange, here, you can find the highest volume ; 1

of not only people but food vendors. Noticeably, l
|

the chairs and tables of The Grange have been
changed since this image was taken in 2008.

Going for rounded tables and fancy chairs and
making way for a far more utilitarian ones. |

Wikki Hut Combo #2 @ Asian infused-South American

“Spicy chicken (with extra sauce for the rice), Andrew Currie (photographer & Reviewer)
steamed broccoli and fresh mango, from one of
my favourite destinations in The Village by the
Grange Food Court.— Andrew Currie on Flickr”

  • o —

-

Tasty Chinese Food @ Chinese
One of the longest standing vendors of the VBTG V. on Yelp (photographer)
still brings in the largest crowd. Tasty Chinese
food has been running for years and there are
pictures all over the Internet to prove it.

Bucking Biggs
1979

“Bucking biggs: Everett Biggs, president of the
Canadian National Exhibition, rides a mechanical bull
at Cowboys bar in Village by the Grange following yes-
terday’s signing of an agreement between the CNE and
the Stetson company which will produce The World’s

Toughest, Rodeo at this year's Ex.

Biggs, Everett (subject)
Spremo, Boris (photographer)

Toronto Star (Firm) (publisher)

Pita Village

“I am not a vegetarian so [ usually order the
chicken shawarma when it is the special which
makes it a reasonable deal. Food is reasonably
tasty for the price and the staff are nice. However,
I do not recommend the pita chips or the cole-
slaw as toppings since they are prone to making
the sandwich spring a leak — Neil P”

@ Mediterranean

V.S. on Yelp (photographer & Reviewer)

Kalbi Dinner Combo

“From the Korean BBQ joint in The Village by
the Grange Food Court.— Andrew Currie on
Flickr”

@ Korean

Andrew Currie (photographer & Reviewer)

Mission Burrito

“Tasty stuff right here! T had the large pork
burrito with everything, except cilantro (because
cilantro is from the devil’s garden). The flavors
were well blended and the tortilla was packed
full of meaty/ricey goodness. My only complaint
is that they were a little skimpy on the guac. —
Chris P. on Flickr”

@ Mexican
Chris P. (photographer & Reviewer)
Rl R e

The lively Grange Square
1979

“Lunch-hour oasis: Diners enjoy the sunny setting of
the market court at Village by the Grange across from

Art Gallery of Ontario”

Bull, Ron (photographer)

Toronto Star (Firm) (publisher)

West of The Village By The Grange
1980

An old couple walks by the Grange admiring shops
as a little child reads on a bench placed on a patch of

grass nearby.

Toronto City Archives

OCADU Library Entrance

Entrance to the OCADU library that remins
today, although with much less colourful interior
design than pictured. Pictures is also a food joint
‘wiki hut’ which is now long gone.

Janice Pearson on Flickr (photographer)

|

Pictured is the old Village By The Grange signage
which is currently replaced by a mural by Jerry Rugg
(Birdo)” This mural is a reflection of community,
nature and artistic expression”— muralroutes.ca.

Jason Paris on Flickr (photographer)

contents.title: description
contents.content_html:
The Village by the Grange archive is a collection of postcards and are.na channels that were part of a research project conducted over the course of 3 months. The postcards feature images, reviews, locations, and in some cases the cuisine of what were once, small businesses that shut down but had left traces on the internet of their memory.

In the context of my time at OCAD, the postcards serve as a tangible memory of what once was in a place that is ever-changing due to the economic fluctuations and lives of the vendors who make the spaces, places.
contents.content:
The Village by the Grange archive is a collection of postcards and are.na channels that were part of a research project conducted over the course of 3 months. The postcards feature images, reviews, locations, and in some cases the cuisine of what were once, small businesses that shut down but had left traces on the internet of their memory. 

In the context of my time at OCAD, the postcards serve as a tangible memory of what once was in a place that is ever-changing due to the economic fluctuations and lives of the vendors who make the spaces, places.

intention is to perpetuate an ‘authentic’
Indian atmosphere to whatever it is

which then became the blueprint for

generations will use these fonts to
appeal to foreign audiences as well as
a handful of second-generation immi-
grant children. “These sorts of designs
come up where you have young people
who cross cultures and languages and
want to show it in their designs.” Says
KV Sridhar, chief creative officer of
Sapient Nitro digital agency, when he
visited a tattoo studio to look for tattoo
ideas for his daughter.

contents.title: 2.jpg
contents.content_html:
CONTENTS

01

INTRODUCTION

This chapter introduces and
gives an insight into this new
type classification system,
why it was created and what
differentiates and categorizes
certain fonts into this category.
It also addresses some im-
portant questions

FAUX
DEVANAGARI

Devanagaris faux counterpart
can be found in the most obvi-
ous of places including India.
In this chapter we discuss
what makes faux devanagari
fonts recognizable and why
they have persisted in the west
as long as they have as well as
discussing it's history.

FAUX HANZI

In this chapter we address
faux Hanzi and it's history.
We talk about how Hanzi is
the first typeface to be appro-
priated and used in history
and why this ended up in the
financial favour of Chinese
immigrants in the USA.

FAUX HANGUL

The most scarce faux type
out of the ones dicussed, faux
Hangul has seen a rise. In this
chapter we discuss why that
is, the difficulty of translating
Hangul into a Latin form and
how it compares in terms of
structure to Latin.

FAUX ARABIC

This chapter compares Arabic
to Latin script and showcases
how Arabic is closer to

Latin than Chinese in terms
of it's characteristics. We also
discuss how Arabic diacritics
are used in these faux Arabic
typefaces whilst comparing
different fonts.

REFERENCES

Image sources and research
credits.

Type is speech made visible, with all
the nuances, inflections, tonalities, and

even dialects of the human voice.
— Jan White, Editing by Design.

CONTENTS

01

INTRODUCTION

This chapter introduces and
gives an insight into this new
type classification system,
why it was created and what
differentiates and categorizes
certain fonts into this category.
It also addresses some im-
portant questions

FAUX
DEVANAGARI

Devanagaris faux counterpart
can be found in the most obvi-
ous of places including India.
In this chapter we discuss
what makes faux devanagari
fonts recognizable and why
they have persisted in the west
as long as they have as well as
discussing it's history.

FAUX HANZI

In this chapter we address
faux Hanzi and it's history.
We talk about how Hanzi is
the first typeface to be appro-
priated and used in history
and why this ended up in the
financial favour of Chinese
immigrants in the USA.

FAUX HANGUL

The most scarce faux type
out of the ones dicussed, faux
Hangul has seen a rise. In this
chapter we discuss why that
is, the difficulty of translating
Hangul into a Latin form and
how it compares in terms of
structure to Latin.

FAUX ARABIC

This chapter compares Arabic
to Latin script and showcases
how Arabic is closer to

Latin than Chinese in terms
of it's characteristics. We also
discuss how Arabic diacritics
are used in these faux Arabic
typefaces whilst comparing
different fonts.

REFERENCES

Image sources and research
credits.

Type is speech made visible, with all
the nuances, inflections, tonalities, and

even dialects of the human voice.
— Jan White, Editing by Design.

contents.title: description
contents.content_html: Faux Script is a publication that analyses a category of typography that focuses on Latin typefaces that mimic the characteristics of non-Latin scripts. These typefaces are often designed to evoke a sense of "exoticism" associated with their source scripts. In my exploration, I specifically focused on Faux typefaces inspired by Hanzi, Arabic, Devanagari, and Hangul and discussed their cultural implications.
contents.content: Faux Script is a publication that analyses a category of typography that focuses on Latin typefaces that mimic the characteristics of non-Latin scripts. These typefaces are often designed to evoke a sense of "exoticism" associated with their source scripts. In my exploration, I specifically focused on Faux typefaces inspired by Hanzi, Arabic, Devanagari, and Hangul and discussed their cultural implications.

contents.title: description
contents.content_html:
Sontag is a community library who's habitat is the 6th floor in 100McCaul st. The shelf was built on the blueprints of the late Enzo Mari.

In response to mass production of goods (namely furniture) The user became a passive consumer, and not an active user of an object and of a process, leading to yet another path of alienation. For myself (as a woman who was taught that such things were a mans job), Sontag became a symbol of demystifying the process and building a stable piece of furniture that stands to be helpful to not just one person, but a community of people.
contents.content:
Sontag is a community library who's habitat is the 6th floor in 100McCaul st. The shelf was built on the [blueprints](https://blog.lostartpress.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/01/enzo_shelves1.jpg) of the late Enzo Mari. 

In response to mass production of goods (namely furniture) The user became a passive consumer, and not an active user of an object and of a process, leading to yet another path of alienation. For myself (as a woman who was taught that such things were a mans job), Sontag became a symbol of demystifying the process and building a stable piece of furniture that stands to be helpful to not just one person, but a community of people.

contents.title: description
contents.content_html:
designed in collaboration with Alexandra, Aaryan, Sanchari and Amir.

This was the first Student Press release since it's hiatus due to COVID19 restrictions. Once printed, we hosted an event called The pearl market to disseminate it to OCAD students and faculty.
contents.content:
designed in collaboration with [Alexandra](https://al-xndram.github.io/), [Aaryan](https://a-p.space), Sanchari and [Amir](https://13-8.world). 

This was the first Student Press release since it's hiatus due to COVID19 restrictions. Once printed, we hosted an event called The pearl market to disseminate it to OCAD students and faculty.

contents.title: description
contents.content_html:
Parchment echo is an experimental film centered around the hypothetical obliteration of immutable documents (paper). The video features archival footage as well as footage from my personal archives of instances that lead to questions of documents and their materiality, juxtaposing the everyday with the bureaucratic. All of this takes place in the underpinnings of a greater narrative- the creation of borders: particularly Pakistan and India. In the background, my other tells the story of reuniting with her grand-uncle who was left behind during the partition of 1947.

The film can be found on this website
contents.content:
Parchment echo is an experimental film centered around the hypothetical obliteration of immutable documents (paper). The video features archival footage as well as footage from my personal archives of instances that lead to questions of documents and their materiality, juxtaposing the everyday with the bureaucratic. All of this takes place in the underpinnings of a greater narrative- the creation of borders: particularly Pakistan and India. In the background, my other tells the story of reuniting with her grand-uncle who was left behind during the partition of 1947.

[The film can be found on this website] (https://runamoto.github.io/parchmentecho/)

contents.title: screenshot-2025-03-25-at-3.02.55-pm.png
contents.content_html:
Parchment Echo

For best experience, project this video and turn the volume all the way up

0:00/2:23 o) ee———@ T3I

The 'obliteration' of an object, the decomposition and deconstruction of it's systemic and cultural canons.
What did this manifest as for paper? An invention that I believe would have materialized in every timeline
of human existance. It's effects on the world incomprehensable and it's origins sylvan. If your birth
certificate, passport, ID, work permit, study permit, diplomas, drivers license, social security card, heath
